Ingredients:

  • 1 cup glutinous rice
  • 4 cups water
  • 3/4 cup cocoa powder
  • 1 cup sugar (adjust to taste)
  • 1/2 teaspoon salt
  • Evaporated milk (optional)
  • Tuyo (dried fish) or milk (optional for serving)

Instructions:

  1. In a large saucepan, combine glutinous rice and water. Bring it to a boil over medium heat, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for about 15 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.

  2. In a separate bowl, whisk together cocoa powder, sugar, and salt with a small amount of water to create a smooth chocolate mixture.

  3. Slowly pour the chocolate mixture into the simmering rice while continuously stirring. Make sure to incorporate it well to avoid lumps.

  4. Continue cooking over low heat for about 15-20 minutes or until the rice is fully cooked and the mixture has thickened to a porridge-like consistency. Stir occasionally to prevent the rice from sticking to the bottom of the pot.

  5. Taste the champorado and adjust the sweetness by adding more sugar if desired.

  6. Once the champorado is cooked, remove it from the heat. You can serve it hot or let it cool down slightly.

  7. To serve, ladle the champorado into bowls. You can drizzle some evaporated milk on top for added creaminess if desired.

  8. Champorado can be enjoyed on its own, or you can pair it with tuyo (dried fish) for a contrasting salty flavor. You can also serve it with milk instead of tuyo if you prefer.

  9. Stir the champorado before eating to distribute the flavors evenly.

Serve and enjoy your comforting bowl of champorado!

Note: You can adjust the thickness of the champorado by adding more or less water according to your preference.
